title: AirCast: Improving Air Pollution Forecasting Through Multi-Variable Data Alignment
author: Vishal Nedungadi (Wageningen University and Research), Muhammad Akhtar Munir (Mohamed bin Zayed University of AI), Marc Rußwurm (Wageningen University and Research), Ron Sarafian (Weizmann Institute of Science), Ioannis N. Athanasiadis (Wageningen University and Research), Yinon Rudich (Weizmann Institute of Science), Fahad Shahbaz Khan (Mohamed bin Zayed University of AI), Salman Khan (Mohamed bin Zayed University of AI), ...
relevance_why: The paper's methodology for multi-variable forecasting can inspire similar approaches in audio generation tasks by integrating diverse data sources, such as environmental factors affecting sound events.
background: This study focuses on accurately forecasting particulate matter concentrations in regions affected by high air pollution using integrated weather and air quality datasets.
contribution: AirCast introduces a multi-variable forecasting model that integrates weather and air quality data to improve the accuracy of air pollution forecasts, especially during severe pollution events.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Traditional models either focus solely on physics-based simulations or limited variable sets, resulting in less accurate forecasts.
technical_comparison.novelty: AirCast combines multi-task learning, frequency-weighted loss, and domain-informed variable selection, leading to improved forecasting accuracy in high-pollution areas.

key_innovation: Employs a Frequency-weighted Mean Absolute Error loss function that emphasizes extreme pollution events, thus enhancing model training and predictions.
real_world_impact: This model can greatly improve public health responses to air quality alerts, enabling timely interventions to protect vulnerable populations from pollution-related health risks.
limitations: The study focuses exclusively on the MENA region, which may limit applicability to other geographic regions without further adaptation.

new_terms.multi-variable forecasting: **Multi-variable forecasting** refers to predicting outcomes by considering several interrelated variables instead of relying on a single predictor, which enhances the accuracy of models.
new_terms.Frequency-weighted Mean Absolute Error: **Frequency-weighted Mean Absolute Error (fMAE)** is a loss function that assigns different weights to errors based on how frequently they occur, prioritizing rarer and potentially more impactful outcomes.

open_sourcing: Source code and models are publicly available at https://github.com/vishalned/AirCast.git
